Input.threadtitle: Infidelity as a subgenre of Marriage movies?
Input.posts:
Although infidelity results from a marriage (or a couple) situation, it may constitute in itself a movie theme. Not always is infidelity triggered by a bad or unhappy marriage. An example of that is Fatal Attraction where a happy married life is disrupted by a third person with whom the husband has an intense affair. I'd like to have some opinions and/or examples of this topic.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I we have to say definitively 'it is' or 'it isn't,' I would say that it would depends on whether or not the main focus of the film is the affair (in which case I think it would be a subgenre of the romance film) or on the marriage itself and the impact that the infidelity has on it (in which case it might qualify as a subgenre of the marriage film). . . . but then of course I think there are still films that don't fit neatly into either box--Scorsese's adaptation of Age of Innocence, for example, which focuses more on Archer's affair with the Countess than it does on his relationship with his fiancée/wife . . . but what the film ends up seeming most interested in is not either relationship per se, but more how they 'fit' into the society of the day (which the marriage is certainly a very significant part of, but it seems to be viewed mostly externally, and gets very little screen time).

Input.threadtitle: Gaslight: Marriage movie or not?
Input.posts:
I was watching the fifth lecture, and when Professor Basinger asked for us to try to figure out which movies were marriage movies and which weren't, the first film that popped into my head was Gaslight (1944), with Ingrid Bergman, Charles Boyer, Angela Lansbury and Joseph Cotten. So I started thinking about it. It's certainly not strictly a marriage movie, more like film noir, but I was thinking about Professor Basinger's question as to whether the plot hinged on the characters being married or not. I think in this case, it absolutely does. In what other situation besides marriage could Charles Boyer have exercised that kind of power over Ingrid Bergman (unless he was another member of her family, a father or a brother)? The two of them have to live in the same house and she has to trust him enough to do what he wants and believe what he says. I don't think the film would be as suspenseful as it is if they were merely two people living together, even if he did know about her aunt's murder and carried out all the same actions. The fact that he is her husband makes the events of the film more potent and horrifying--it makes it even harder for her to get away, and because he's her husband it doesn't occur to her that he is the instigator, so she blames her own mind. Thoughts, anyone? Anne

2

Instructor's Post
Interesting case. If I had to come up with an argument for it NOT being a marriage movie, I think it would be that the marriage in the film is not really a legitimate marriage, but rather a means to the end of finding the jewels.

I was watching the fifth lecture, and when Professor Basinger asked for us to try to figure out which movies were marriage movies and which weren't, the first film that popped into my head was Gaslight (1944), with Ingrid Bergman, Charles Boyer, Angela Lansbury and Joseph Cotten. So I started thinking about it. It's certainly not strictly a marriage movie, more like film noir, but I was thinking about Professor Basinger's question as to whether the plot hinged on the characters being married or not. I think in this case, it absolutely does. In what other situation besides marriage could Charles Boyer have exercised that kind of power over Ingrid Bergman (unless he was another member of her family, a father or a brother)? The two of them have to live in the same house and she has to trust him enough to do what he wants and believe what he says. I don't think the film would be as suspenseful as it is if they were merely two people living together, even if he did know about her aunt's murder and carried out all the same actions. The fact that he is her husband makes the events of the film more potent and horrifying--it makes it even harder for her to get away, and because he's her husband it doesn't occur to her that he is the instigator, so she blames her own mind. Thoughts, anyone? Anne

Input.threadtitle: Week 2: Laurel and Hardy as 'marriage movie'.
Input.posts:
Utterly loving the course so far...i love dissecting the factors that make marriage movies, marriage movies. :) Having said that, I have to admit Professor Basinger's mention several times of 'Laurel and Hardy' as a marriage movie is a little frustrating to me. Gender aside, L&H lack a core factor for a marriage movie: they're not married. I think of that as the 'so unnecessary as to not have to mention it' criteria #1. It's like saying 'Bogart and Hepburn in 'The African Queen' is like a marriage movie'...but they aren't married, That's, as my kids would call it, a 'deal-breaker'. ;) L&H's relationship clearly has some of the fundamentals Basinger believes is crucial to the marriage movie: the 'bickering', the 'union in movement and action', the day to day alliance. But they lack something major- they're not actually married to each other. So references to it as such seem counter-productive. Why do you think it is that this has been mentioned more than once, when there was so much time spent outlining the fundamental definition of marriage movie? Is this idea challenging anyone else?
Upvotes:
6
In lecture #8 Prof. Basinger lists the 3 elements of a marriage movie: 1. The couple 2. Their problems 3. The situations they find themselves in Perhaps I took the word 'marriage' too literally in trying to identify movies that qualify as marriage movies. But given the 3 elements above, there seems no reason to limit couples to those who are actually married in the film. It may be enough that there is togetherness between the couples to qualify as a marriage movie.
Upvotes:
4
Christy, you raise a good question. I look at Prof. Basinger's usage of Stan & Ollie as a good example of the dynamics of a couple in a marriage movie, even though by the literal definition they aren't married. I think those dynamics between Laurel and Hardy are one of the things that have endeared them to audiences for the last 90+ years. Having that 'chemistry' onscreen is a key piece of the marriage movie, as was also discussed regarding other key Hollywood pairings like Tracey and Hepburn, Bogart and Bacall, and more recently with couples like Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan (ok, not that recent) or Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson. Just as interesting to me was the clip from Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House (Potter, 1948) at the end of the last lecture for week #2. I hadn't paid much attention to the scene with the alarm clock before, but this shows a dynamic between the two that--even though they are barely awake--they anticipate each others actions and movements. The fact that Blandings has to negotiate his way through all of his wife's belongings to get to his dressing gown is also crucial to the motivation for the rest of the plot.
